title: Tenant Deposit Rights (General)
text: Tenants have a legal right to receive their security deposit back at the end of tenancy if there is no major damage. Steps: (1) Request refund from landlord in writing with a copy of the rental agreement, (2) Ask for an itemized list if deductions are made, (3) If landlord refuses, file a complaint with the Rent Controller or Consumer Forum, (4) Emergency disputes can also be reported to Police Helpline 100. Example: In 'Sharma vs Gupta (Delhi, 2018)', the court ordered refund of full deposit plus interest.

title: Consumer Right - Refund for Defective Goods
text: A defective product gives the buyer the right to a refund, repair, or replacement. Steps: (1) Report defect to the seller/website immediately, (2) Keep invoice, warranty card, and communication as evidence, (3) If no resolution within 30 days, file a complaint at the District Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (< Rs. 1 crore value), (4) Call National Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000 or complain online at consumerhelpline.gov.in. Example: In 'Rajesh vs XYZ Electronics (2019)', the company was ordered to refund and pay compensation for harassment.

title: Cyber Fraud - Online Banking Scam
text: Online fraud and unauthorized banking transactions are punishable offences. Steps: (1) Call National Cybercrime Helpline 1930 immediately to freeze transactions, (2) File complaint at cybercrime.gov.in with transaction details, (3) Visit nearest police station or cyber cell and file FIR under IT Act Section 66C/66D, (4) Inform your bank in writing and request chargeback. Example: In 'State of Maharashtra vs ABC (2020)', cybercriminals were booked under IT Act and IPC for online fraud.

title: Delayed Salary - Labour Rights
source: Payment of Wages Act, 1936 & Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
text: Employees must be paid salary before the 7th or 10th of the next month depending on company size. Steps: (1) Send written complaint to employer/HR with proof, (2) Approach Labour Commissioner office if not resolved, (3) File case at Labour Court/Industrial Tribunal. Helpline: Ministry of Labour 155214. Example: In 'Ravi vs ABC Pvt Ltd (2017)', the Labour Court ordered payment of three months pending salary with interest.

title: Minimum Wages Protection
text: Workers are entitled to at least the notified minimum wage. Steps: (1) Verify current minimum wage notification for your state, (2) If employer pays less, lodge a complaint with Labour Commissioner, (3) Call Labour Helpline 155214. Example: In 'Kumar vs Textile Mills (2016)', underpaid workers received arrears after court intervention.

title: Right to Information (RTI)
text: Any citizen can seek information from a government office. Steps: (1) Draft RTI application with name, address, and information needed, (2) Pay Rs. 10 fee (online or postal order), (3) Submit to the Public Information Officer (PIO) of the department, (4) If no reply within 30 days, file appeal to First Appellate Authority. Online portal: rtionline.gov.in. Example: In 'RTI by Meera (2015)', information about pending ration card applications was provided within 21 days.

title: Domestic Violence Protection
source: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
text: Victims can get legal and police protection against abuse. Steps: (1) Call Women Helpline 181 or Police 100 for immediate help, (2) Approach Protection Officer or District Legal Services Authority, (3) File complaint in Magistrate Court for protection, residence, or monetary relief. Example: In 'Seema vs Rajesh (2012)', the court granted immediate residence order to the victim.

title: Dowry Harassment
text: Demanding or giving dowry is illegal. Steps: (1) Call Women Helpline 1091 or NCW Helpline 7827170170, (2) File FIR at police station under Dowry Prohibition Act and IPC Section 498A, (3) Approach Womenâ€™s Cell for counseling and support. Example: In 'Anita vs In-laws (2014)', accused were jailed for dowry harassment.

title: Marriage and Divorce
text: Divorce can be sought on grounds like cruelty, desertion, or mutual consent. Steps: (1) Collect marriage certificate, ID proof, and grounds, (2) File petition in Family Court, (3) Attend hearings, (4) Court grants decree if satisfied. Free legal aid: Helpline 1516. Example: In 'Kavita vs Ramesh (2019)', the court granted mutual consent divorce within six months.

title: Child Labour
text: Employing children below 14 in hazardous jobs is illegal. Steps: (1) Report case to Childline 1098 immediately, (2) Inform District Labour Office, (3) Authorities will rescue and rehabilitate child workers. Example: In 'Childline Rescue Operation (2017)', dozens of minors were freed from a factory.

title: Workplace Sexual Harassment
text: Every workplace must have an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC). Steps: (1) File written complaint to ICC within 3 months, (2) If no ICC exists, approach District Officer/Local Complaints Committee, (3) Call Women Helpline 181 for support. Example: In 'Neha vs IT Company (2018)', the ICC ordered termination of the accused and compensation.

title: SC/ST Atrocities Protection
text: Discrimination or violence against SC/ST individuals is a criminal offence. Steps: (1) File FIR at police station citing SC/ST Act provisions, (2) Contact SC/ST Helpline 1800-1800-214, (3) Seek free legal aid via District Legal Services Authority. Example: In 'State vs Accused (2015)', court awarded compensation to SC victim of caste assault.

title: Lok Adalat - Free Dispute Resolution
text: Lok Adalats provide free and speedy settlement of disputes. Steps: (1) Approach District/State Legal Services Authority with case details, (2) Submit dispute application, (3) Attend Lok Adalat session, (4) Award is binding and final. Example: In 'Ramesh vs Suresh (2016)', a cheque bounce case was settled in Lok Adalat without lengthy trial.

title: Emergency Helplines (India)
text: For immediate help, use these helplines: Police 100 | Ambulance 108 | Fire 101 | Women Helpline 181 | Childline 1098 | Cybercrime 1930 | Consumer 1800-11-4000 | Labour 155214 | Legal Aid 1516 | SC/ST 1800-1800-214.
